title: Collecting Data with Tally Marks
description: Learn to collect and organise data using tally marks and picture graphs
objectives: Collect data by asking yes/no questions and counting
Read and create simple picture graphs

sections.title: Let's Collect Some Data!
sections.content:
Have you ever wondered what your classmates' favourite colour is, or how many students walk to school? To find out, you need to **collect data**!

**Data** is information we gather by counting, measuring or asking questions. Once we have data, we can organise it so it's easy to understand.

sections.title: Tally Marks
sections.content:
**Tally marks** are a quick way to count as you collect data. Here's how they work:

| Count | Tally marks |
|-------|------------|
| 1 | $\mid$ |
| 2 | $\mid\mid$ |
| 3 | $\mid\mid\mid$ |
| 4 | $\mid\mid\mid\mid$ |
| 5 | $\mid\mid\mid\mid\!\!\diagup$ (the fifth mark goes across) |
| 6 | $\mid\mid\mid\mid\!\!\diagup \;\mid$ |
| 7 | $\mid\mid\mid\mid\!\!\diagup \;\mid\mid$ |

The **fifth mark** crosses over the first four to make a group of 5. This makes it easy to count by 5s!

**Example:** If 12 students like vanilla ice cream:
$$\mid\mid\mid\mid\!\!\diagup \quad \mid\mid\mid\mid\!\!\diagup \quad \mid\mid = 5 + 5 + 2 = 12$$

sections.title: Picture Graphs
sections.content:
A **picture graph** (or pictograph) uses pictures or symbols to show data. Each picture represents one item (or sometimes more).

sections.title: Example: Reading a Tally Chart
sections.content:
Here is a tally chart of pets owned by students:

| Pet | Tally | Total |
|-----|-------|-------|
| Dog | 8 tallies | ? |
| Cat | 6 tallies | ? |
| Fish | 3 tallies | ? |
| Bird | 2 tallies | ? |

sections.title: Asking Good Questions
sections.content:
To collect data, you need to ask a **clear question**. Good data questions have answers you can count or sort.

**Good questions:**
- "What is your favourite colour?" (you can count each colour)
- "How did you get to school today?" (walk, car, bus, bike)
- "Do you have a pet? Yes or No" (yes/no questions are the simplest)

**Not-so-good questions:**
- "Do you like things?" (too vague!)
- "What do you think about everything?" (can't count or sort the answers)

The best questions give you data that you can organise into clear categories.

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Super work! In this lesson you learned:

- **Data** is information we collect by counting or asking questions
- **Tally marks** help us count quickly (groups of 5)
- **Picture graphs** use symbols to show data visually
- Ask **clear questions** with answers you can count or sort

Try collecting some data! Ask your family what their favourite food is and make a tally chart.

workedExamples.title: Counting Tally Marks
workedExamples.problem: A tally chart shows 13 tally marks for 'chocolate'. How would these be written?
steps: First group of 5: four vertical marks with one across
Second group of 5: four vertical marks with one across
Total: two groups of 5 plus 3 = 13 âœ“
workedExamples.solution: Two complete groups of 5 tally marks plus 3 extra marks = **13**.
workedExamples.explanation: Tally marks are grouped in 5s so you can skip count: $5, 10, 13$.

workedExamples.title: Reading a Picture Graph
workedExamples.problem: A picture graph shows: Sunny days = 7 suns, Rainy days = 4 clouds, Cloudy days = 3 clouds. How many more sunny days than rainy days?
steps: There were 3 more sunny days than rainy days
workedExamples.solution: There were **3 more sunny days** than rainy days.
workedExamples.explanation: To find 'how many more', we subtract: $7 - 4 = 3$.

title: Chance: Likely and Unlikely Events
description: Describe the chance of events happening using everyday language
objectives: Describe events as likely, unlikely, certain or impossible
Compare the chance of different events
Order events from least likely to most likely

sections.title: What Are the Chances?
sections.content:
Will it rain tomorrow? Will you see a dinosaur on the way to school? Some things are very likely to happen, and some things will definitely never happen!

**Chance** is about how likely something is to happen. In maths, we use special words to describe chance.

sections.title: Words for Describing Chance
sections.content:
We use these words to describe how likely an event is:

| Word | What it means | Example |
|------|--------------|----------|
| **Certain** | It will definitely happen (100%) | The sun will rise tomorrow |
| **Likely** | It will probably happen | It will rain sometime this month |
| **Unlikely** | It probably won't happen | It will snow in Melbourne in January |
| **Impossible** | It can never happen (0%) | You will grow wings and fly |

We can put these on a line from least likely to most likely:

$$\text{Impossible} \leftarrow \text{Unlikely} \leftarrow \text{Even chance} \rightarrow \text{Likely} \rightarrow \text{Certain}$$

**Even chance** (or fifty-fifty) means it's just as likely to happen as not happen -- like flipping a coin.

sections.title: Example: Sorting Events by Chance
sections.content: Sort these events: A) Rolling a 7 on a normal dice, B) The school bell ringing at the end of the day, C) Picking a red ball from a bag of 9 red balls and 1 blue ball.
steps: A) A normal dice has numbers 1-6. You can't roll a 7. This is **impossible**.
B) The school bell rings every day at the end of the day. This is **certain**.
C) 9 out of 10 balls are red, so picking red is very **likely**.
Order from least to most likely: **Impossible** (A), **Likely** (C), **Certain** (B)

sections.title: Chance Can Change!
sections.content:
The chance of something happening can change depending on the situation.

**Example with a bag of marbles:**
- Bag with 5 red and 5 blue: picking red is an **even chance** (fifty-fifty)
- Bag with 8 red and 2 blue: picking red is **likely**
- Bag with 1 red and 9 blue: picking red is **unlikely**
- Bag with 0 red and 10 blue: picking red is **impossible**
- Bag with 10 red and 0 blue: picking red is **certain**

The more red marbles there are compared to blue, the more likely you are to pick a red one.

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Awesome job! In this lesson you learned:

- **Chance** describes how likely something is to happen
- Key words: **certain**, **likely**, **unlikely**, **impossible**
- **Even chance** means equally likely to happen or not
- The chance of an event depends on the **situation**

Think about events in your day -- which are certain, likely, unlikely or impossible?

workedExamples.title: Describing the Chance of Events
workedExamples.problem: Describe the chance of each event: A) You will eat food today, B) A pig will fly past your window, C) It will be sunny tomorrow.
steps: A) Everyone needs to eat food every day -- this is **certain**
B) Pigs cannot fly -- this is **impossible**
C) It might be sunny or it might not -- this is **likely** or **unlikely** depending on the weather forecast
workedExamples.solution: A) **Certain**, B) **Impossible**, C) **Likely** or **Unlikely** (depends on the season and location).
workedExamples.explanation: Events that always happen are certain. Events that can never happen are impossible. Events that might or might not happen fall somewhere in between.

workedExamples.title: Comparing Chances
workedExamples.problem: A bag has 7 green balls and 3 yellow balls. Is it more likely to pick a green ball or a yellow ball?
steps: Since $7 > 3$, there are more green balls
It is more likely to pick a green ball
workedExamples.solution: It is **more likely** to pick a green ball because there are more green balls (7) than yellow balls (3).
workedExamples.explanation: When there are more of one colour, you're more likely to pick that colour. Green (7 out of 10) is more likely than yellow (3 out of 10).
